Award.AwardTitle: ELT: Collaborative Research: Restructuring of terrestrial environments following the Permian-Triassic mass extinction
Award.AbstractNarration:
ELT COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: RESTRUCTURING OF TERRESTRIAL ENVIRONMENTS FOLLOWING THE PERMIAN-TRIASSIC MASS EXTINCTION.

Christian Sidor, University of Washington
Peter Roopnarine, California Academy
Kenneth Angielczyk, Field Museum of Natural History, Chicago, Illinois
Sterling Nesbitt, Virginia Technological University

Understanding the broad-scale effects of climate change in deep time (between 245 and 120 million years ago) and its associated mass extinction, on terrestrial communities has been hindered by the lack of high-quality regional or global-scale data, as nearly all studies have been restricted to sequences in Russia or South Africa. This research will build on six prior seasons of fieldwork in Tanzania and Zambia (together TZAM) to bring new data to bear on this major linked event of environmental, climatic, and biotic change. Our team will gather multidisciplinary data (sedimentological, geochemical, vertebrate paleontological, paleobotanical, and geochronological) during two proposed seasons of fieldwork. In the lab, we will use geographic distribution and community food web models to address more general questions about mass extinctions and their subsequent recoveries. For example, do mass extinctions consistently cause certain types of community restructuring or do their effects vary with environment and geography? Does the ecological rebuilding of terrestrial communities proceed in a stereotyped way, regardless of the exact identities of the species involved? Answering these types of questions is an important step in the process of moving from documenting the causes and effects of this extinction event, to using it as a source of predictive information for dealing with modern biotic crises.
Vertebrate paleontology fascinates the public. Because of their visibility, dissemination of our results to the general public will primarily occur at the natural history museums involved in the project. In collaboration with the exhibits departments at the Field Museum and Burke Museum, we will create two exhibit installations focusing on Asilisaurus kongwe, a small dinosaur relative from Tanzania that is an icon of our research project. At the conclusion of the grant, the installations will be permanently transferred to the National Museum of Tanzania (Dar es Salaam, Tanzania), and the Livingstone Museum (Livingstone, Zambia) where they will introduce local citizens to the rich paleontological heritage of their nations. We will also develop a level of the FMNH's paleontology video game Game of Bones focusing on Asilisaurus. The game level will be centered around discovering and excavating a specimen of Asilisaurus, reconstructing its anatomy, and making inferences about its paleobiology. The game level will be promoted on the main websites of the Field Museum of Natural History (FMNH), University of Washington Burke Museum (UWBM), and the California Academy of Science (CAS), the museums' social media sites, and web pages targeting science enthusiasts (e.g., FMNH: Science@FMNH, The Field Revealed; UWBM: BurkeBlog; CAS: Science Today and Science in Action).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Occurring about 252 million years ago, the Permian-Triassic mass extinction (PTME) is the largest mass extinction in Earth history, and it had lasting effects on the structure and composition of ecosystems on land and in the ocean. Rapid global warming, caused by huge volcanic eruptions in what is now Siberia, appear to have played a major role in the PTME, making it highly relevant for studies of the impact of modern human-induced climate change. Our best record how land ecosystems ere affected by the PTME, and recovered in its aftermath, comes from rocks preserved in South Africa. However, it has proven difficult to determine whether the changes observed there are indicative of global patterns or if they preserve a more regional signal of change. This project seeks to expand our picture of how the PTME affected land ecosystems by studying fossils preserved in Zambia and Tanzania. Both countries have excellent records of land animals from the time just before and shortly after the PTME, but they have received relatively little interests from paleontologists. Learning about the ancient ecosystems of Tanzania and Zambia is a key step in determining whether the record preserved in South Africa reflects local or global effects of the PTME.


With funding from this grant, our research group conducted five seasons of fieldwork in Permian and Triassic rocks in Tanzania and Zambia. Among the discoveries resulting from this work are several new species of the ancient mammal relatives that dominated land ecosystems before the PTME, as well as new relatives of crocodiles and dinosaurs that played a key role in the recovery following the extinction. More broadly, our work shows that land ecosystems across southern Africa were relatively uniform in structure and composition before the PTME. However, the extinction fragmented these communities, and communities in Tanzania and Zambia recovered differently from that in South Africa, with crocodile and dinosaur relatives playing a much more important role in Tanzania and Zambia. The way in which animals interacted with each other in the recovered communities also differed between Tanzania and Zambia on one hand and South Africa on the other, showing that there are multiple ways to rebuild stable ecosystems after a mass extinction. Our multi-disciplinary research has firmly established these previously-understudied areas as premier locations for studying the PTME and encapsulates the synthetic approach to paleontological research promoted by the Earth-Life Transitions program.


We have used a number of strategies to bring our science to the general public. This includes engaging museum members and volunteers as citizen scientists who help to unpack our fossils when they come back from the field and prepare them for study. Our project was the focus of a temporary exhibit at Chicago?s Field Museum of Natural History, and new content about the PTME and replicas of specimens we collected are now part of the museum?s permanent paleontology exhibit. We produced a freely-available educational video game about paleontlogy based on our research that is intended to be used as a lab exercise for introductory college classes on geology and Earth history. Discoveries made in the course of our work, such as the early dinosaur relative Teleocrater rhadinus, were the subject of substantial media attention that brought our work to a global audience. Finally our project has important role in capacity-building. Several postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduates have contributed to our project as part of their training, helping to build the next generation of researchers. Likewise, all of the specimens collected in Tanzania and Zambia will eventually be returned to museums in those nations, where they will be an important scientific resource for years to come.
